children: A 33-year-old woman is evaluated for double vision. Examination shows dysconjugate eye movements and nystagmus.
Brain MRI
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

text.__html: Primary angiitis of the central nervous system

children: This patient's MRI shows multiple, ovoid-shaped, hyperintense foci consistent with multiple sclerosis (MS) plaques, the characteristic MS lesion seen on MRI. Pathologically, plaques consist of a discrete region of demyelination with relative preservation of axons. Plaques suggestive of MS are typically found on MRI in the periventricular region, corpus callosum, centrum semiovale, and, to a lesser extent, deep white matter structures and basal ganglia. MS plaques usually have an ovoid appearance, and lesions are arranged at right angles to the ventricles, as if radiating from this area. The plaques appear hyperintense on proton density–weighted and T2-weighted studies and are hypointense (if visible at all) on T1-weighted images. Active plaques may enhance with contrast.
A 57-year-old man with hypertension and epilepsy is evaluated for numerous skin nodules, located primarily on his trunk, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The skin findings shown are most consistent with cutaneous neurofibromas. The defining characteristics of neurofibromatosis type 1 (von Recklinghausen disease) are multiple cutaneous neurofibromas (benign nerve sheath tumors) and café au lait macules. Cutaneous neurofibromas are recognized as soft, sessile, or pedunculated tumors, with most occurring on the trunk. Neurofibromas vary in number from just a few to several hundred, and they increase in number and size with age. They do not carry an increased risk of malignant transformation but may be cosmetically significant. Other manifestations of neurofibromatosis type 1 include hypertension, epilepsy, soft tissue sarcomas, cognitive deficits, and hypertension.

title: Question 3

children: A 45-year-old woman is evaluated for acute-onset facial dissymmetry. Findings are
shown
as she attempts to smile.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is Bell palsy, an idiopathic paralysis of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) that leads to unilateral paralysis of upper and lower facial muscles, as is seen in this patient. In contrast, upper facial muscles are spared in central facial weakness (stroke) because of their bilateral innervation. Altered taste and hyperacusis also may occur in Bell palsy because of involvement of chorda tympani and stapedius muscles. In classic Bell palsy, initial brain imaging and laboratory testing are not required.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 61-year-old woman is evaluated for sudden paralysis of the right side. A CT scan without contrast taken 7 hours after symptom onset (
left panel
) and 24 hours after symptom onset (
right panel
) are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is ischemic stroke. This patient's initial CT scan (left panel) is unremarkable, showing no evidence of hemorrhagic stroke, which would appear as a white density within the gray brain tissue, or infarction. The initial noncontrast head CT in ischemic stroke is often normal, but within 24 to 48 hours after onset of stroke symptoms, the ischemic brain tissue becomes edematous, resulting in a hypodense region on CT scan, as seen on this patient's follow-up CT scan (right panel). If the edema is significant, a mass effect may be seen with shift of midline structures (as is seen on the follow-up scan) and obliteration of the basilar cisterns. CT is insensitive for the presence of herpes simplex encephalitis, but temporal lobe hypodensities may be seen in severe cases.
A 40-year-old woman with recently diagnosed advanced HIV infection is evaluated for altered mental status and hemianopia.
Brain MRI
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), which is caused by reactivation of the polyomavirus JC (JCV). PML-associated demyelination is confined to the subcortical white matter and the cortex. On
MRI

, PML presents as a discrete unilateral or bilateral foci of demyelination-appearing hyperintense lesions without mass effect. Diagnosis requires polymerase chain reaction testing for the presence of JCV and occasionally brain biopsy. In contrast, cerebral toxoplasmosis and primary central nervous system lymphoma cause discrete mass lesions whereas neurosyphilis is associated with non-specific changes on MRI.
A 50-year-old man is evaluated for headache.
Brain MRI
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is meningioma, which is the most common primary type of central nervous system tumor. Often found incidentally, meningiomas are benign, dural-based tumors that typically show homogenous enhancement on postcontrast MRI. They have a smooth, rounded shape and often a “tail” that tracks along the dura outside the
brain parenchyma
arrow
A 40-year-old man is evaluated after falling off a 6-foot ladder and striking his head.
CT scan of the head is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Subdural hematoma is the most likely diagnosis. Subdural hematoma is readily visualized on a CT scan of the head as a high-density crescentic collection across the hemispheric convexity. Subacute and chronic subdural hematomas appear as isodense or hypodense crescent-shaped lesions that deform the surface of the brain. The images
shown
below reveal a crescentic lesion over the left hemisphere (
red arrows

In contrast to a subdural hematoma, an epidural blood hematoma produces a convex pattern inward toward the brain parenchyma on CT scan because expansion of the hematoma is limited by firm dural attachments at the cranial sutures in the epidural space.

objective.__html: Diagnose a subdural hematoma based on CT findings.

children: A 78-year-old woman is evaluated for a tremor, as shown.
(Note that there is no sound for this
video
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient has essential tremor, the most common movement disorder. Essential tremor often presents with a bilateral upper extremity postural and action tremor. As seen in the video, it is commonly present when the arms are outstretched but is not seen when the arms are relaxed and not held against gravity. This type of tremor may also involve the voice, head, or legs. Common features include a positive family history (50% of patients), slow progression, and onset at either adolescence or middle age.
A 52-year-old woman is evaluated for sudden onset of right-sided weakness that has progressed since symptoms began 1 hour ago.
CT scan is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This CT scan suggests intracerebral hemorrhage. CT is highly sensitive for diagnosing hemorrhage in the acute setting. Intracerebral hemorrhages are evident almost instantly after onset as focal white hyperdense lesions within the brain parenchyma, as seen in the left hemisphere on the image shown. Intracerebral hemorrhages can also be detected by MRI, and the use of susceptibility sequences improves the sensitivity of MRI for early detection of a hemorrhage. Lobar hemorrhages near the cortical surface may result from hypertension, hemorrhagic tumors, cortical vein thrombosis, or cerebral amyloid angiopathy.
A 40-year-old woman is evaluated for a
droopy eyelid
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient's physical examination demonstrates right ptosis and miosis and is most consistent with Horner syndrome (oculosympathetic paresis). Horner syndrome results from a lesion in the cervical sympathetic chain and is defined by miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis.
A 38-year-old man with polycystic kidney disease undergoes cerebral angiography. His father also had polycystic kidney disease and died of a stroke at the age of 52 years.
Results of cerebral angiography are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is cerebral aneurysm. This cerebral angiogram
shows

a 4.5-mm saccular anterior communicating artery aneurysm. Extrarenal manifestations of polycystic kidney disease include intracranial aneurysms (detected in 5% to 10% of patients, with a strong familial pattern) as well as hepatic cysts (detected in >80% of patients over their lifetime), mitral valve prolapse, and inguinal and umbilical hernias. The Guidelines for the Management of Patients with Unruptured Intracranial Aneurysms from the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association recommend that patients with a history of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, particularly those with a family history of intracranial aneurysm, should be offered screening by CT angiography (CTA) or MR angiography (MRA). The location and size of the aneurysm are the primary determinants of rupture risk, and both MRA and CTA can show these features noninvasively.
A 70-year-old man is evaluated for an abnormal gait, as shown.
(Note that there is no sound for this
video
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is Parkinson disease. Parkinson disease has four cardinal signs: tremor at rest, bradykinesia, rigidity, and gait/balance impairment. Resting tremor is characteristically unilateral at onset and remains asymmetric. Bradykinesia is characterized by slowness and gradual lessening of the amplitude of repetitive movements; this feature is often associated with reductions in facial expression and arm swing. Rigidity, manifesting as increased resistance to movement, is often asymmetric and may occur on the same side as tremor. Gait disturbance manifests as a slow, narrow-based, and shuffling gait with associated reduced arm swings, stooped posture, and imbalance when turning. As the disease progresses, severe freezing of gait and postural instability are noted. This video demonstrates the tremor, reduced facial expressions, limited arm swings, imbalance when turning, and stooped posture characteristic of Parkinson disease.
A 21-year-old man is evaluated for newly diagnosed temporal lobe epilepsy.
Brain MRI
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely neuroimaging diagnosis?
The most likely neuroimaging diagnosis is mesial temporal sclerosis. The coronal flair MRI
shows
increased signal intensity and atrophy of the right mesial temporal lobe (
white arrow

) consistent with mesial lobe sclerosis, a surgically treatable form of epilepsy. Temporal lobe epilepsy is the most common adult-onset focal epilepsy. Typical symptoms include aura, loss of awareness, staring, behavior arrest, and amnesia. Automatisms, repetitive semipurposeful movements (such as lip smacking, chewing, and swallowing), and picking or grabbing movements with the ipsilateral arm are common. Speech arrest may be seen with involvement of the dominant hemisphere. Mesial temporal sclerosis with hippocampal atrophy is the most common cause of medication-resistant, adult-onset focal epilepsy.

objective.__html: Diagnose mesial temporal sclerosis as a cause of epilepsy.

children: A 68-year-old man is evaluated for apathy, poor cognition, impaired gait, and occasional urinary incontinence.
Brain MRI is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is normal pressure hydrocephalus. The MRI shows ventricular dilation typical of normal pressure hydrocephalus. The diagnosis is suggested by an expansion of the entire ventricular system in the absence of (or disproportionate to) cortical atrophy or an obstruction to outflow of cerebrospinal fluid (such as aqueductal stenosis). Periventricular hyperintensities may also be seen.
A 17-year-old boy is evaluated for diminished level of consciousness following a motor vehicle accident.
Head CT
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Critique

The most likely diagnosis is epidural hematoma. This patient's CT demonstrates the typical appearance of an epidural hematoma with a hyperintense collection with a convex appearance. An epidural hematoma arises when an arterial structure is breached and blood collects between the dura mater and skull in this “lentiform” fashion. Lateral extension is limited by dural attachments at the skull sutures, and expansion occurs inward toward the brain parenchyma. Most epidural hematomas involve a laceration of the middle meningeal artery from a temporal bone fracture.
A 54-year-old woman is evaluated for unresponsiveness following a thunderclap headache.
CT angiogram is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is subarachnoid hemorrhage. This patient's CT angiogram
shows

an extensive subarachnoid hemorrhage (blood appearing as white hyperintense areas) with intraventricular extension. CT is very sensitive for detection of subarachnoid hemorrhage, especially when performed soon after symptom onset. Examination findings suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage include altered mental status, nuchal rigidity, pupillary dilation from compression of the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) by a posterior communicating artery aneurysm, or subhyaloid hemorrhages on funduscopy. The most common cause of atraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage is saccular (berry) aneurysm rupture, with intracranial arterial dissection and mycotic aneurysm rupture occurring less commonly.
A 36-year-old woman is evaluated for severe, unrelenting headache.
Funduscopic findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is papilledema. This image shows typical features of papilledema, including an elevated optic disc and indistinct disc margins. Early papilledema causes blurring of the upper and lower nasal disc margins. Later, the physiologic cup is obscured. With progression, blurring extends to the diverging vessels and veins become distended and pulseless. As the disc surfaces elevate, the emerging vessels can also be seen to bend sharply as they pass over the elevated disc. Papilledema is caused by increased intracranial pressure, such as occurs with brain tumor, obstructive hydrocephalus from any cause, and occasionally hypertensive emergency.
